segment.source: Configure Client Computers (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure Client Computers (Windows 10)

segment.source: Configure Client Computers
segment.target: Configure Client Computers

segment.source: Configure Client Computers
segment.target: Configure Client Computers

segment.source: To enable the Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT) to function correctly, certain configuration changes are required on all client computers:
segment.target: To enable the Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT) to function correctly, certain configuration changes are required on all client computers:

segment.source: An exception must be set in the client computer's firewall.
segment.target: An exception must be set in the client computer's firewall.

segment.source: A registry key must be created and set properly, for computers in a workgroup; otherwise, Windows® User Account Control (UAC) will not allow remote administrative operations.
segment.target: A registry key must be created and set properly, for computers in a workgroup; otherwise, Windows® User Account Control (UAC) will not allow remote administrative operations.

segment.source: Organizations where the VAMT will be widely used may benefit from making these changes inside the master image for Windows.
segment.target: Organizations where the VAMT will be widely used may benefit from making these changes inside the master image for Windows.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: This procedure only applies to clients running Windows Vista or later.
segment.target: This procedure only applies to clients running Windows Vista or later.

segment.source: For clients running Windows XP Service Pack 1, see Connecting Through Windows Firewall.
segment.target: For clients running Windows XP Service Pack 1, see Connecting Through Windows Firewall.

segment.source: Configuring the Windows Firewall to allow VAMT access
segment.target: Configuring the Windows Firewall to allow VAMT access

segment.source: Enable the VAMT to access client computers using the Windows Firewall Control Panel:
segment.target: Enable the VAMT to access client computers using the Windows Firewall Control Panel:

segment.source: Open Control Panel and double-click System and Security.
segment.target: Open Control Panel and double-click System and Security.

segment.source: Click Windows Firewall.
segment.target: Click Windows Firewall.

segment.source: Click Allow a program or feature through Windows Firewall.
segment.target: Click Allow a program or feature through Windows Firewall.

segment.source: Click the Change settings option.
segment.target: Click the Change settings option.

segment.source: Select the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) checkbox.
segment.target: Select the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) checkbox.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: By default, Windows Firewall Exceptions only apply to traffic originating on the local subnet.
segment.target: By default, Windows Firewall Exceptions only apply to traffic originating on the local subnet.

segment.source: To expand the exception to apply to multiple subnets, you need to change the exception settings in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, as described below.
segment.target: To expand the exception to apply to multiple subnets, you need to change the exception settings in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security, as described below.

segment.source: Configure Windows Firewall to allow VAMT access across multiple subnets
segment.target: Configure Windows Firewall to allow VAMT access across multiple subnets

segment.source: Enable the VAMT to access client computers across multiple subnets using the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Control Panel:
segment.target: Enable the VAMT to access client computers across multiple subnets using the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Control Panel:

segment.source: VAMT Firewall configuration for multiple subnets
segment.target: VAMT Firewall configuration for multiple subnets

segment.source: Open the Control Panel and double-click Administrative Tools.
segment.target: Open the Control Panel and double-click Administrative Tools.

segment.source: Click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Click Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: Make your changes for each of the following three WMI items, for the applicable Network Profile (Domain, Public, Private):
segment.target: Make your changes for each of the following three WMI items, for the applicable Network Profile (Domain, Public, Private):

segment.source: Windows Management Instrumentation (ASync-In)
segment.target: Windows Management Instrumentation (ASync-In)

segment.source: Windows Management Instrumentation (DCOM-In)
segment.target: Windows Management Instrumentation (DCOM-In)

segment.source: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI-In)
segment.target: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI-In)

segment.source: In the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security dialog box, select Inbound Rules from the left-hand panel.
segment.target: In the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security dialog box, select Inbound Rules from the left-hand panel.

segment.source: Right-click the desired rule and select Properties to open the Properties dialog box.
segment.target: Right-click the desired rule and select Properties to open the Properties dialog box.

segment.source: On the General tab, select the Allow the connection checkbox.
segment.target: On the General tab, select the Allow the connection checkbox.

segment.source: On the Scope tab, change the Remote IP Address setting from "Local Subnet" (default) to allow the specific access you need.
segment.target: On the Scope tab, change the Remote IP Address setting from "Local Subnet" (default) to allow the specific access you need.

segment.source: On the Advanced tab, verify selection of all profiles that are applicable to the network (Domain or Private/Public).
segment.target: On the Advanced tab, verify selection of all profiles that are applicable to the network (Domain or Private/Public).

segment.source: In certain scenarios, only a limited set of TCP/IP ports are allowed through a hardware firewall.
segment.target: In certain scenarios, only a limited set of TCP/IP ports are allowed through a hardware firewall.

segment.source: Administrators must ensure that WMI (which relies on RPC over TCP/IP) is allowed through these types of firewalls.
segment.target: Administrators must ensure that WMI (which relies on RPC over TCP/IP) is allowed through these types of firewalls.

segment.source: By default, the WMI port is a dynamically allocated random port above 1024.
segment.target: By default, the WMI port is a dynamically allocated random port above 1024.

segment.source: The following Microsoft knowledge article discusses how administrators can limit the range of dynamically-allocated ports.
segment.target: The following Microsoft knowledge article discusses how administrators can limit the range of dynamically-allocated ports.

segment.source: This is useful if, for example, the hardware firewall only allows traffic in a certain range of ports.
segment.target: This is useful if, for example, the hardware firewall only allows traffic in a certain range of ports.

segment.source: For more info, see How to configure RPC dynamic port allocation to work with firewalls.
segment.target: For more info, see How to configure RPC dynamic port allocation to work with firewalls.

segment.source: Create a registry value for the VAMT to access workgroup-joined computer
segment.target: Create a registry value for the VAMT to access workgroup-joined computer

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: This section contains information about how to modify the registry.
segment.target: This section contains information about how to modify the registry.

segment.source: Make sure to back up the registry before you modify it; in addition, ensure that you know how to restore the registry, if a problem occurs.
segment.target: Make sure to back up the registry before you modify it; in addition, ensure that you know how to restore the registry, if a problem occurs.

segment.source: For more information about how to back up, restore, and modify the registry, see Windows registry information for advanced users.
segment.target: For more information about how to back up, restore, and modify the registry, see Windows registry information for advanced users.

segment.source: On the client computer, create the following registry key using regedit.exe.
segment.target: On the client computer, create the following registry key using regedit.exe.

segment.source: Navigate to
segment.target: Navigate to

segment.source: Enter the following details: Value Name: LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicyType: DWORDValue Data: 1Note
segment.target: Enter the following details: Value Name: LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicyType: DWORDValue Data: 1Note

segment.source: To discover VAMT-manageable Windows computers in workgroups, you must enable network discovery on each client.
segment.target: To discover VAMT-manageable Windows computers in workgroups, you must enable network discovery on each client.

segment.source: Deployment options
segment.target: Deployment options

segment.source: There are several options for organizations to configure the WMI firewall exception for computers:
segment.target: There are several options for organizations to configure the WMI firewall exception for computers:

segment.source: Image.
segment.target: Image.

segment.source: Add the configurations to the master Windows image deployed to all clients.
segment.target: Add the configurations to the master Windows image deployed to all clients.

segment.source: Group Policy.
segment.target: Group Policy.

segment.source: If the clients are part of a domain, then all clients can be configured using Group Policy.
segment.target: If the clients are part of a domain, then all clients can be configured using Group Policy.

segment.source: The Group Policy setting for the WMI firewall exception is found in GPMC.MSC at: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsWindows Firewall with Advanced SecurityWindows Firewall with Advanced SecurityInbound Rules.
segment.target: The Group Policy setting for the WMI firewall exception is found in GPMC.MSC at: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsWindows Firewall with Advanced SecurityWindows Firewall with Advanced SecurityInbound Rules.

segment.source: Script.
segment.target: Script.

segment.source: Execute a script using Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager or a third-party remote script execution facility.
segment.target: Execute a script using Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager or a third-party remote script execution facility.

segment.source: Manual.
segment.target: Manual.

segment.source: Configure the WMI firewall exception individually on each client.
segment.target: Configure the WMI firewall exception individually on each client.

segment.source: The above configurations will open an additional port through the Windows Firewall on target computers and should be performed on computers that are protected by a network firewall.
segment.target: The above configurations will open an additional port through the Windows Firewall on target computers and should be performed on computers that are protected by a network firewall.

segment.source: In order to allow VAMT to query the up-to-date licensing status, the WMI exception must be maintained.
segment.target: In order to allow VAMT to query the up-to-date licensing status, the WMI exception must be maintained.

segment.source: We recommend administrators consult their network security policies and make clear decisions when creating the WMI exception.
segment.target: We recommend administrators consult their network security policies and make clear decisions when creating the WMI exception.

segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: Install and Configure VAMT
